title: CTRL0000082293 - Transcribed Interview of Audra Joy Lemons-Johnson, (April 20, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The deposition in the above matter was held via Zoom, commencing at 2:10 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
Let's go on the record at 2:09 p.m. for the deposition of Audra
This is a deposition of Audra Lemons-Johnson conducted by
the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States
Ms. Johnson, please state your full name and spell your last name for the record.
And would you please raise your right hand to be sworn
Do you solemnly declare and affirm under the penalty of perjury
that the testimony you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing
So this is going to be a staff-led deposition, and members, of course, may choose
to ask questions, but I don't see any on the Webex with us right now, but if they do join,
they could also ask you questions.
And on the Zoom with us today is
So we will follow the House deposition rules that we've provided to your counsel
My name i s _ , investigative counsel with
Under the House deposition rules, you are permitted to have an attorney
Ms. Johnson, at this time, I'm going to ask your counsel to please state his
Thank you very much, Mr. Dulan.
And under the House deposition rules, neither committee members nor staff may
discuss the substance of testimony you provide today unless the committee approves
You and Mr. Dulan will have an opportunity to review the transcript of this
And before we begin, I'd like to describe a few ground rules.
official reporter transcribing the record of this deposition.
The reporter also is joining us
by Zoom, so please wait until each question is completed before you begin your response,
and we will try to wait until your response is complete before we ask our next question.
It's just very hard with, you know, the remote deposition for the court reporter to hear
voices talking at the same time.
like to remind myself and everyone else to make sure we're not talking over each other.
And the reporter also cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your
And I know I'm -- I've been bad at it before, so I always
head, so it is important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
For the benefit of the reporter and the record, there may be times where I spell a name
or a word that we are using, or that I ask that you do the same.
And we ask that you provide complete answers based on your best recollection.
If the question is not clear, which may happen, please ask for clarification.
not know the answer, please simply say so.
Logistically, if you need any breaks for comfort or to talk to Mr. Dulan about
microphones, turn our cameras off, and you guys can have a conversation or take
So like I said, throughout this deposition, we will be directing your attention to
exhibits, which will be displayed on the screen.
And when we refer you to a document
you can take your time to familiarize yourself with it before we discuss it.
So I am going to show you exhibit 1.
Can you see it now, Mr. Dulan?
I hear a video playing though.
Yeah, I was hearing the audio but also looking at the subpoena.
That is the exhibit, Ms. Johnson.
All I see is the subpoena.
So do you recognize this subpoena
as the one that the select committee served to you?
So under the subpoena, you may
only refuse to answer a question to preserve a privilege recognized by the select
proceed with the deposition, or seek a ruling from the chairman on the objection.
chairman overrules such an objection, you are required to answer the question.
If you refuse to answer a question based on a privilege, staff may either
And at this time, I would ask that Mr. Dulan please place on the record any
objections that he might have or make any opening remarks that he might have.
No, we don't have any blanket objections.
Want to remind you, as we do with all witnesses, that it is unlawful to deliberately
false information could result in criminal penalties to include for perjury and/or providing
Since this deposition is under oath, providing
You broke up a little bit.
I was saying that since this deposition is under oath,
providing false information could result in criminal penalties, including perjury and
providing false statements, and it's just -- it's unlawful to deliberately provide false
We tell that to all witnesses.
And if I could,_, I'm sorry, we should make -- there's one
statement that should be made right now, which is that my client reports that she no
longer has the same cell phone that she had during the relevant timeframe, so she was
unable to obtain some texts, and possibly some other documents.
provided 256 pages total, I believe it is.
reported to me and should be noted here to get everything.
However, there was a lack of ability that's been
So we'll get into the substantive questions now and just start with a little bit
And where do you currently live?
How long have you lived there?
We moved here the 26th, I believe, of March.
I lived in Battle Creek for about a year before we moved here, but for the
Have you lived in that area of Michigan though for a while?
most part, yes, I've lived in Michigan around the same area, yes.
Those are both -- those are both jobs in my book.
So are you -- do you have any former law enforcement background or
And what do you currently do for a job?
I work at home taking care of kids and my elderly parents.
The Michigan Liberty Militia doesn't really exist anymore, except for like in
Are you a member of the Michigan Liberty
title, so, I mean, I can't even remember the last time we ever even did anything.
Were you at one time a member?
And was the militia in existence between November 2020 and January 2021?
Again, it was more like a title, not really, you know, doing anything, so I don't
consider that in existence, but you might.
So what drew you to, when it was still active, be a part of the
I believe we all have the constitutional right to defend ourselves, and I like
When there was a flood here in Michigan, they went
When we had really cold weather, they -- we went out and gave
coats to the homeless and fed the homeless.
the militia went and delivered clean water.
When Flint made a call for clean water,
I don't recall, like years ago maybe, maybe 2017, maybe.
So when did you actually end up joining?
And just for one second, I think your phone and your
so we don't have an echo?
Do you want to mute yourself on the computer just
How did you learn about the Michigan Liberty Militia?
I'm trying to recall, I think the very first time I really even learned about
Sorry, I'm not good with dates.
the militia came out and supported the rally.
What kind of rally was it?
There was a rally that I held and
And would you say that this militia supported -- this was the
There was several militias there, if I remember correctly.
Do you remember the names of the other ones?
What was it, like Michigan Home Guard?
I don't recall having them there, no.
Something called the Michigan Militia Corps of Wolverines?
How about Michigan Lanterns of Liberty?
In terms of their -- were they there supporting
President Trump, then, at your rally?
From my experience with the militia, I mean, of course, everybody has a,
like, leaning of what they believe in, but for the most part, when the militias come to a
rally it's to support freedom of speech for both sides.
So were there protesters at that rally then?
I'm sorry, honey, I can't -- I can't hear anything.
I said, were there protesters at that rally?
So when you did join the Michigan Liberty Militia, was there
like a formal process you had to go through to become a member?
And do you know who leads the group, or led the group?
I'm sorry, did I ever lead the group?
A patriot that I've been friends with for quite a while.
What does he do for a living?
Do you know who is the leader of the group or who led the group?
I -- that's always been my assumption of it.
Do you know how or why he founded the Michigan Liberty Militia?
Do you know how many people were in the militia?
I couldn't give you a certain number.
It's kind of like a running joke, everybody called me Commander Honey
Did you -- did you, yourself, have any, like, title in the militia?
That's not just that militia, like everybody calls me Commander Honey
Patriots across the State, I guess.
Why did you get that nickname?
I think Phil was the first one to call me Honey
Was there any reason for it?
It's kind of like a nickname.
But you said, you know -- you said groups across the State call
How -- which groups are you talking about?
I couldn't -- there's not a specific group.
kind of just, like I said, a nickname that I got from, you know, being outspoken.
So are there other militia groups then that you associate with or
Maybe there's Genesee -- God, I don't even know their real -- the full name.
Genesee Volunteer Militia, you know, Home Guard.
formal meetings or, like, really gatherings of things like that.
So what would you say -- why would you say you associate with them, or
Why would I say associate with them, could you clarify?
Like you mentioned that those two groups are ones that, you know, might
how do you associate with those groups then?
I've never really gone to, like, any
So I'm wondering like, what is your connection to those groups?
I just have been to, like, a lot of rallies and protests and things and met, you
know, hundreds and thousands of people across Michigan.
And these militias are some of the ones that have shown up at your rallies?
I mean, I've only personally held like two rallies, but I couldn't say for certain
which groups showed up at my rallies or not.
I guess, what, in your mind, made the Michigan Liberty Militia a
Well, you know, traditionally the militias in our country have been more of a
So to me, it was more just like, you know, I like what these
Like it's like, Okay, there's a flood, hundreds of people lost everything they had, and the
militia came out and cleaned up after the flood.
matter what side it was, the militia were there to make sure that things went peacefully.
I mean, they've protected both Republicans and Democrats in that kind of, you know,
When their neighbors needed their help they, you know, they ran.
There's, you know, a rally going on, no
Does the term "militia," though, have any sort of connection to firearms or
I suppose it does, but, I mean, in my mind, every American citizen is a militia
Everyone has the right to protect themselves and their country, so that wasn't
That wasn't like what had drawn me to it.
But, I guess, then how, in your mind, what is the difference
between the militia and like government services that are meant to respond to floods or
to protect people's free speech rights?
Because they don't do it a lot.
I mean, I'm just being honest.
had the dams break here in Michigan, those people didn't get any help from the
It was the militia that was out there helping.
Does the Michigan Liberty Militia coordinate with government entities, or
work with anyone in law enforcement to do these things?
I can tell you that I have heard -- like I haven't been participating in setting
up the militias being at rallies or anything like that, but I've heard they do contact the
police departments to let them know they're going to be there.
And is that sort of the same thing, when there's an environmental
disaster, they'll coordinate with government agencies?
Yes, they'll let the police know that they're going to be out there helping,
Were you aware of how the Michigan Liberty Militia or other
militias across Michigan communicated with one another, like, did they use messaging
apps like Signal or Telegram, or primarily, Face book or anything like that?
My communication with them was like primarily through Facebook, and, you
know, I'm not as deep into the militia, so I don't know.
Maybe -- yeah, I don't -- I don't know for certainty.
I'm going to go through a -- the names of a couple of possible
militia groups, and asking if you know if the Michigan Liberty Militia, you know, worked
with these groups at all, so --
I think so, but, again, I -- I wasn't involved in that, so I --
Does the name Ryan Kelley ring a bell for you?
Everybody -- yeah, everyone knows Ryan Kelley.
And do you know that he founded the American Patriot Council?
I know he was sort of like -- I guess, I assumed he was like the leader of the
I couldn't tell you for certain if he founded it.
But do you think that Ryan Kelley worked with the Michigan Liberty
I've seen pictures of, like, Phil and the guys that were with that.
That doesn't even ring a bell.
Have you ever heard of the Boogaloo Boys?
Yeah, everyone has heard of the Boogaloo Boys.
So did they ever work with the Michigan Liberty Militia?
Do you know if the Michigan Liberty Militia worked with any Three
Have you ever heard of Three Percenters?
Percenters or any Three Percenters were members of their group?
I -- I couldn't say for certain.
Percenters is a pretty big thing all over the country, but I -- I don't know for certain.
, I think I might turn it over to you now.
I want to ask about a couple of events in Michigan from early 2020.
Were you involved in the April 15, 2020, Operation Gridlock event around
Hi, Ms. Johnson, thanks so much for being with us today.
My signal is not the greatest.
You just tell me if you can't hear a question that I have
I told people about it, but I didn't, like, officially help, you
And were you there just as an individual or as part of the Michigan
I don't -- I don't know for certain if they even went to
So is it fair to say you didn't have a role in the actual event, just as a
I didn't like -- I wasn't part of the official like, I don't know, quote/unquote,
Can you give me a sense of kind of what the atmosphere was like in
terms of people's views of Governor Whitmer and what was happening in Michigan at the
I mean, obviously, people were upset.
the events that day is there was just a lot of people who were expressing their First
Amendment right to protest when they're upset with the government.
I believe it was the emergency lockdowns.
There's a lot of protests that
So I believe that was the, like, central issue of that
Did you hear people threatening Governor Whitmer at that
I can't -- I don't -- I don't remember that much in detail.
It was a long time ago.
Were you at the April 30th event that was at the State Capitol in
I believe that was Ryan Kelley's group that organized it.
encouraged people to go inside and be vocal about their objections to what was
Why was it important to go inside?
We always go inside the Capitol, so it was kind of, like, it's something we
My phone is being really junkie right now.
Why was it important to go inside the Capitol?
normally did and to, you know, be very vocal about their -- people's, you know,
disagreement with what the government was doing.
What were you -- I'm sorry, I don't understand what the -- what the -- can
you explain what the protest was about?
I believe, if I remember correctly, it was about the vote to give
Whitmer an extension on emergency powers, if I recall correctly.
There was a lot of people there armed.
We -- it's not a -- it's not like
a -- and it might seem weird to you, but it's not a weird or out-of-place, like, thing to have
We've had probably dozens of protests where we carry our guns.
But help me understand why it's important to carry guns inside the
It's just our right to carry our guns.
I'm telling you from, like, my point of view, I couldn't speak for other people,
but it's just kind of our right to carry guns.
I mean, that's -- it always happens.
-- what message do you think it sends to carry weapons inside the Capitol
If I could interrupt just for a moment.
read the minds of other people.
She already stated that she wasn't armed that day.
I support people practicing their Second Amendment however legally they
Including by going in the Capitol Building?
Could you repeat that name, please?
Do you support people going into the Capitol armed?
Do you know someone named Mike Sparks?
I -- there's a lot of VouTube channels, and there's a lot of, like,
And you mentioned that Ryan Kelley organized the event.
describe your relationship with Ryan Kelley, how long you've known him?
How long have I known him, maybe late 2019 -- no, it's got to be like 2020.
Do you remember how you got connected with him?
I'm sorry, I -- this -- I'm trying to think.
I think he was holding a rally in
Do you remember what kind of rally it was?
Speaking of Grand Rapids, there was an event that Ryan Kelley
organized on May 18th in Grand Rapids.
Did you happen to attend that?
It was an event organized by Ryan Kelley, the American Patriot Council, in
I mean, I know I did attend one in Grand Rapids, but I couldn't tell
you offhand if it was that specific one.
It was an event where Mike Shirkey was there, Dar Leaf was there.
Yes, I did attend that one.
Do you remember who organized that?
Assuming it's American Patriot Council, so I'm assuming the group that Ryan
I don't know how to put it other than that.
And it seems like you recognized Mike Shirkey and Dar Leaf.
Do you have relationships with either of them?
I know Dar Leaf, not very intimately though.
few conversations with him, but I don't consider him, like, a friend or anything like that.
I don't even know if I have actually spoke to the man, so I wouldn't consider
I do not, to be honest.
Did you have any role in organizing the event?
I don't think so, other than, maybe, like, posting, like, Hey, there's going to
Do you remember what the event was about?
They were part of Michigan Liberty Militia.
Do you know the Null twins?
Would you frequently see them at events?
I don't -- I think April 30th was probably the last, like,
event -- the first event in a while that I had seen them.
I haven't spoke with them for -- ever.
Do you still have a relationship with them?
I -- yeah, no, I haven't seen them
No -- no, well, I haven't spoken to them.
Are you aware that they're suspected in the kidnapping plot of
Yeah, it actually really does surprise me.
I mean, they know the Constitution.
What do you mean by constitutionalist?
Is that all that makes a constitutionalist?
knowledgeable on it, I guess I'll say.
I think most people believe in the
I believe in the Constitution as the
Bill and Mike are very huge
constitutionalists, so, yeah, it surprised me a lot.
I've spoken to their wife, like,
I don't know what other people think about
I would call them a constitutionalist because they're very
But I guess I don't understand, because you described them as
constitutionalists, so I want to get a sense of what you mean by that term.
So in my mind, in my thinking, a constitutionalist is somebody that
believes the Constitution is what governs our country.
I can't tell you what other people think a constitutionalist is.
Why do you think people who plotted to kidnap the Governor are
I couldn't tell you what their mindset is, or why they did what they did, but
as far as I know, they haven't been convicted guilty of it yet.
I know very little about that.
Ms. Johnson, come on, you described them as constitutionalists after you
told me that you knew that they were accused in the plot to kidnap Governor Whitmer.
I'm just trying to understand how you square the two things.
Well, because I knew them and the relationship that I knew them.
even think it would even be capable of them doing, or being accused of something like
what I knew them as, and as what was presented -- how they presented themselves to
So perhaps how I knew them is different than what they are.
Did you ever hear members of the Michigan Liberty Militia talking about
people like Governor Whitmer in kind of derogatory terms, talking about wanting to harm
Not that I can think of.
You never heard anyone from the Michigan Liberty Militia talking about
Did you participate in any other events with the Michigan Liberty Militia over
Did you do anything with the Michigan
Liberty Militia over the summer of 2020?
Were you aware of any of the Black Lives Matter or antifa-related protests in
I mean, there's been a few, yeah.
Did you attend any of those as a counter protester?
say how much I love my militia family.
these rallies are planned and staffed."
This is a Facebook post where you wrote, "I can't
I've been so stressed trying to make sure all
What rallies were you planning and staffing?
I can actually explain that to you.
So I was working with Katherine
Henry's Restore Freedom coalition, and she was asking me to organize their -- it was like a
like, rallies and stuff, and so, I was just saying how much I -- this wasn't my picture.
didn't take this picture, at least I don't re -- think I did.
thank you for being there to attend the rallies.
And the militia members were organ -- or meeting up at these different,
And I was saying, Hey, you guys,
So this wasn't something I attended.
So what was your role in the rallies?
I was working as an event organizer, so, like, I would -- somebody would call
Katherine Henry and say, Hey, I would like to have a petition rally or something like that,
and I would say, Okay, Hey, this is the people in your area that you can get a hold of so
they can come and attend the rally.
And aren't these people members of the Michigan Liberty Militia?
And what was the event about?
This one was for Restore Freedom petition.
almost certain this was for Restore Freedom petition.
So what it was, Katherine Henry, who's a constitutionalist lawyer, was
putting up a petition to pretty much nullify the 1945 and 1976 bill, I believe.
Were there other events that you helped plan or you served as an
Well, this wouldn't have been a militia-related event.
of confused, because this wasn't like a militia thing.
This was a Restore Freedom thing.
They're not part of the militia that you're part
of, and you wrote, I can't say how much I love my militia family.
I consider anybody who, I guess, is part of the patriot movement or the
I don't know what else to tell you about that.
I'm confused, too, because this isn't even a militia event.
I can't specifically tell you, like, what groups are part of --
Just tell me what, you know, what makes someone part of the patriot
And who's part of the patriot movement?
I would say pretty much somebody who's -- I mean not even conservative,
but just wants to have general constitutional rights for the American people.
So if people don't identify as part of the patriot movement, do you
think that they want people to have constitutional rights?
I guess that would be on a case-by-case basis.
Black Lives Matter freedom of speech before.
I mean, I've stood up for
And when did you do that?
I would've looked up these dates if I had the
right -- I don't know, June 2020 maybe or 2021.
I saw a group -- I'm sorry?
Did you go to a Black Lives Matter event?
Did you go to an event?
I was downtown Grand Rapids cleaning up after Grand Rapids had
burned, and I saw two Black Lives Matter people peacefully protesting.
were going to arrest them, and I said, I had asked you before if people would be arrested
and you said it was up to your discretion.
Lives Matter protesters who were peacefully protesting, and I said you can't arrest them
for using their freedom of speech.
They were going to arrest these two Black
Was that the -- did you go to any other Black Lives Matter events?
I -- are you asking that year?
There were plenty of Black Lives Matter events in summer
I asked you earlier, you said you didn't remember.
So I'm asking if you -No, that was not a Black Lives Matter event.
people peacefully protesting, and I wasn't there to attend that event or to
If you -- if you have a specific, like, thing you want to ask, that's fine.
Who do you think burned down Grand Rapids?
Who do I think burned down Grand Rapids?
screaming Black Lives Matter while they were doing it, so I would assume it's part of that.
Why do you think Black Lives Matter was burning down Grand
Did Michigan Liberty Militia, to your knowledge, were they involved
in counter-protesting or protecting counter-protesters at those events?
Any other events that you participated in in summer 2020?
That day I believe they did go by request of the Black Lives Matter.
I was in Sanford cleaning up the dam damage.
I'll turn it back to you.
Ms. Johnson, I'm going to turn our attention to after the November 2020 election.
-- timeframe in mind for going forward.
Following the 2020 election, did you believe that the election was stolen
Right away, I thought there was something going on
because, you know, we had heard people, you know, crying out that, Hey, they're not
letting us object to these ballots.
I don't know what else to say to that.
Early on, I kind of figured it would, you know, fix itself.
So you -- when did you transition, then, from thinking it would fix itself into
thinking it had been -- that something wasn't right?
Really, I kind of was under the impression that, you know, there's always
a -- I don't know how to put this.
I figured that the Constitution would take care of it.
That's why I went to January 6th.
I was there to give support to the States that were
going to object to the certification of the vote.
So if you were supporting the States that were objecting to the
certification of the vote, that -- does that mean you thought something was wrong with
And can you expand on that a little bit?
I just thought, like, you know, there's just so much information out there.
know in Michigan we had people who -- I mean, I had people I knew who were at the TCF
Center -- I want to call it Cobo Hall, because that's -- I guess I'm old enough, and that's
what it's always been called -- who were, like, I saw, you know, ballots coming in when
they weren't supposed to come in.
to these ballots that are so ridiculously, like, fraudulent, and they're not letting us.
We had people that were like we're trying to object
And who are these people that were trying to object?
Offhand, I can tell you Dawn Bede (ph), I believe her last name i s , _
Were these just concerned citizens, or did they have specific roles in --
I couldn't tell you the specific roles.
know they were -- so they must have been poll challengers or something like that.
And how are you connected to them?
You know, I've known Don for, I don't know, a year or 2 maybe.
Did you yourself have any role in overseeing the election as it was
Or -- so did you take part in any actions in Michigan afterwards
I don't have the -- I don't possess the authority to challenge the vote, I guess,
so I don't know -- I mean, I don't know -- I guess I don't understand what you're saying.
Were you part of any efforts in Michigan to secure a
I attended some rallies, but I -- I don't -- you know, I was contacted
by -- gosh, I couldn't even tell you who contacted me.
said, Hey, the Trump lawyers are trying to gather information out of Michigan.
hear anything, send them to this number or something like that.
Why do you think that person reached out to you?
Do you remember if you ever sent any information to that number?
I guess because I'm a big voice in Michigan.
Because a lot of it was kind of, like, stupid stuff, like,
Oh, I've used a felt pen instead of a regular pen.
So on that point, just to -- not to divert us too far, what did you consider to
be a stupid, in your words, complaint versus something with more substance?
Maybe, like -- I think somebody had -- I
couldn't vote because they didn't have a mask on.
I think somebody said something about their ballot wasn't accepted or they
But you don't remember if you sent any of those along to that
And did you work at all with the Trump campaign after the November 2020
election in Michigan in any sort of challenge efforts?
And then in terms of the rallies you said you went to, was one of
them outside of the Michigan Secretary of State's house?
The Michigan Secretary of State's house?
I think one was outside the TCF Center and one was outside Lansing maybe.
Would you -- were you part of a Stop the Steal organization in
I mean, I have Stop the Steal sweaters, but, no, I
Do you remember where those protests that you took part in were?
Were you part of any organization challenging the election results in
I think the closest I ever got to being part of an organization was, like -- like,
maybe the Trump Unity Bridge, like --
But nothing specifically in Michigan related to challenging the election,
I believe that's the date, yes.
And did you attend a rally in Washington, D.C. on
November 14, 2020, to support former President Trump?
I don't even remember the dates of the three
I mean, I know January 6th, but -But you do -- you went to three of them then?
Did you have any organizational role for the November 14th rally, or
this -- the second one, December 12, 2020, did you have --
I mean, I might have, like, told people about it and, like, maybe gave a
patriot or two $20 bucks or something, but I didn't -- I wasn't part of the organization.
I saw problems in the election, and I felt I had the right to speak on those
Why did you attend those first two rallies in Washington, D.C.?
problems, to show my support of those problems.
Did you think something specific would happen after attending those rallies,
like what outcome were you hoping for after making your voice heard?
actually preach against that all the time.
Founding Fathers, and they taught us to be defensive, but not offensive.
I guess the outcome I was hoping for was to draw attention to election
You know, I certainly don't support a violent takeover of the government.
You know, we have to do this according to our
I wanted to make sure that there was light shed on the problem, like, I said.
have people who have told me, like, Hey, I was at the TCF Center, some fishy stuff was
And at that point nobody was, like, looking into it.
In terms of election integrity, was that in light -- did you want to shed light
on just the 2020 election or the issue more broadly?
I mean, I would say election integrity is important no matter who wins.
What was her name -- after the 2016 election, Green, I think was her name, she was, you
know, gathering money to look into an audit of the election here in Michigan, and I -- I
didn't, like, come out screaming support of that, but I was, like, Hey, if we have a
problem, we should probably look into it.
And did you hear, let's say around the December 12th rally or so, so around
December 2020, had you heard reports that the 2020 election, by all accounts, was
I mean, I heard that -- I heard it was incredibly secure and accurate, and then
I heard, no, that's not true.
So where did you hear that it was accurate?
Did you hear reports that William Barr, President Trump's attorney general,
that the intelligence services in the United States, and that courts who had looked at
these cases across the country all came out with similar conclusions that there was
nothing really wrong with the 2020 election?
I mean, again, I heard counterintuitive reports.
One says, Yeah, it was the
safest it's ever been, and then there was, you know, the Supreme Court hasn't even
